Adding some clarification

While the D&D Templates use the same class names, you can actually target those class names with your own CSS if need be.

The boilerplate uses it’s own layout.css file. which while it’s essentially the same as the built in layout.css file. It enables you to control what code is there.
<https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/blob/master/src/css/layout.css>
D&D areas does not force the layout.css file like the drag and drop layouts in the design manager does.

DND areas also adds additional classes
> The generic CSS selectors for the drag and drop area components are `.dnd-section`, `.dnd-column`, `.dnd-row` and `.dnd-module`.

> Does my own markup have to be on a 12 col grid?
not directly but you need to accomodate for the fact the markup generated by the DND area tags IS based on a 12 column grid, the width’s and offsets are as well.

So you could say handle all of the class names specified in layout.css handle the DND elements, and have additional classes you use elsewhere like within modules or in your templates wrapping around dnd areas that do not conform to 12 column.
I gave some details previously to someone, but it’s now lost in Slack history. Is there a better place to give this kind of feedback?

> And do I we still have to target the same class names in the layout.css file?
Yes, there is no way to configure the class names used by dnd_area tags
A simple scenario would be needing to make a full width section with background color/image. Adding a class would give a simple way to style the text inside for a light/dark background.

> so if i don´t use the DM, my template can ship without the layout.css?
If you use dnd_area tags, you can use custom CSS, which targets those class names.
-----
If you use the drag and drop layouts in the design manager - the layout.css file is automatically added, because it’s necessary for that type of template to function properly.
